abstract.text: An object for scheduling the playback of buffers or segments of audio files.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: This audio node supports scheduling the playback of
instances, or segments of audio files that you open through
. You can schedule buffers and segments to play at specific points in time or to play immediately following preceding segments.

Generally, you want to configure the node’s output format with the same number of channels as in the files and buffers. Otherwise, the node drops or adds channels as necessary. It’s usually preferable to use an
for this configuration.

Similarly, when playing file segments, the node makes sample rate conversions, if necessary. It’s preferable to configure the node’s output sample rate to match that of the files, and to use a mixer to perform the rate conversion.
When playing buffers, there’s an implicit assumption that the buffers are at the same sample rate as the node’s output format.
The
method unschedules all previously scheduled buffers and file segments, and returns the player timeline to sample time
The
class isn’t key-value observing compliant, and may indicate that Combine publishers are available. Don’t use them for monitoring changes.
The usual
sample times, which
observes, have an arbitrary zero point. The
class superimposes a second player timeline on top of this to reflect when the player starts and intervals when it pauses. The methods
and
convert between the two.
The
, and
methods take an
parameter, and you interpret it as follows:
If the
parameter is
If there are previous commands, the new one plays immediately following the last one.
Otherwise, if the node is in a playing state, the event plays in the very near future.
Otherwise, the command plays at sample time
If the
parameter is a sample time, the parameter interprets it as such.
If the
parameter is a host time, the system ignores it unless the sample time is invalid when the engine is rendering to an audio device.
The scheduling methods fail if:
A buffer’s channel count doesn’t match that of the node’s output format.
The system can’t access a file.
An
doesn’t specify a valid sample time or a host time.
A segment’s start frame or frame count is a negative value.
The buffer of file completion handlers are a means to schedule more data if available on the player node. For more information on the different completion callback types, see
Don’t stop a player within a completion handler callback because it can deadlock while trying to unschedule already scheduled buffers.
When you use a player node with the engine operating in manual rendering mode, you use the buffer or file completion handlers —
, and
— to track how much data the player rendered and how much remains to render.

abstract.text: Play, record, and process audio; configure your app’s system audio behavior.
A collection of properties that define 3D mixing properties.
An object that represents an audio file that the system can open for reading or writing.
An object that takes any number of inputs and converts them into a single output.
A collection of properties that are applicable to the input bus of a mixer node.
An object you use for audio generation, processing, or an I/O block.
The most recent render time.
The processing latency of the node, in seconds.
The maximum render pipeline latency downstream of the node, in seconds.
An object that represents an audio buffer you use with PCM audio formats.
An object for scheduling the playback of buffers or segments of audio files.
Creates an initialized audio player node.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the player is playing.
Converts from player time to node time.
Pauses the node’s playback.
Starts or resumes playback immediately.
Starts or resumes playback at a time you specify.
Converts from node time to player time.
Prepares the file regions or buffers you schedule for playback.
Schedules the playing samples from an audio buffer with the playback options you specify.
Schedules the playing samples from an audio buffer at the time and playback options you specify.
Schedules the playing samples from an audio buffer with the callback option you specify.
Schedules the playing samples from an audio buffer.
Schedules the playing of an entire audio file with a callback option you specify.
Schedules the playing of an entire audio file.
Schedules the playing of an audio file segment with a callback option you specify.
Schedules the playing of an audio file segment.
Clears all of the node’s events you schedule and stops playback.
The buffer options that control the playback scheduling.
Constants that specify when the framework must invoke the completion handler.
The callback handler for buffer or file completion.
A protocol that defines stereo mixing properties a mixer uses.
An object you use to represent a moment in time.
Construct an audio player to play your custom audio data, and optionally take advantage of the advanced features of AirPlay 2.

abstract.text: Add voice-processing capabilities to your app by using audio engine.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
